item.title: Why Taste Buds Dull As We Age
item.description: May 5, 2017 - You're born with roughly 9,000 taste buds, and they're very good at regenerating — which is why you can recover the ability to taste just days after burning your tongue. But that changes as we age.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 5, 2017 - You're born with roughly 9,000 taste buds, and they're very good at regenerating — which is why you can recover the ability to taste just days after burning your tongue. But that changes as we age. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/05/526750174/why-taste-buds-dull-as-we-age

item.title: Denmark Now Has A Wild Wolf Pack Again — For The First Time In 200 Years
item.description: May 4, 2017 - Citing CCTV footage and DNA samples, two researchers say a female has migrated more than 340 miles from Germany to join a small group of wolves in the Jutland peninsula.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - Citing CCTV footage and DNA samples, two researchers say a female has migrated more than 340 miles from Germany to join a small group of wolves in the Jutland peninsula. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/04/526937018/denmark-now-has-a-wild-wolf-pack-again-for-the-first-time-in-200-years

item.title: 5 Things To Watch As GOP Health Bill Moves To The Senate
item.description: May 4, 2017 - Just three "no" votes by Senate Republicans would likely be enough to sink the GOP health bill. Democrats who lost the battle in the House are still convinced they can win the political war.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - Just three "no" votes by Senate Republicans would likely be enough to sink the GOP health bill. Democrats who lost the battle in the House are still convinced they can win the political war. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/04/526922980/gop-health-bill-moves-to-the-senate-5-things-to-watch

item.title: Citizen Scientist Challenges Math Behind Red Light Camera Tickets
item.description: May 4, 2017 - A man in Oregon is challenging the math behind red light camera tickets. Mats Järlström calculates that drivers who end up in an intersection when the light goes yellow can be trapped in a no-win dilemma, particularly if they are making a turn. NPR's Kelly McEvers talks to Aarian Marshall, who wrote about the case for Wired magazine.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - A man in Oregon is challenging the math behind red light camera tickets. Mats Järlström calculates that drivers who end up in an intersection when the light goes yellow can be trapped in a no-win dilemma, particularly if they are making a turn. NPR's Kelly McEvers talks to Aarian Marshall, who wrote about the case for Wired magazine. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/04/526931921/citizen-scientist-challenges-math-behind-red-light-camera-tickets

item.title: America's Protected Natural Areas Are Polluted, By Noise
item.description: May 4, 2017 - A new survey shows that the sound of cars and planes and other forms of noise pollution are rampant across the American wilderness. In many cases, man-made noise is drowning out the background sounds.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - A new survey shows that the sound of cars and planes and other forms of noise pollution are rampant across the American wilderness. In many cases, man-made noise is drowning out the background sounds. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/04/526889161/americas-protected-natural-areas-are-polluted-by-noise

item.title: To Bring Down Stubbornly High Blood Pressure, It Helps To Have A Team
item.description: May 4, 2017 - A quick prescription and annual lecture from a doctor often aren't enough to help people control hypertension. So some clinics now mobilize teams of health pros to motivate and support patients.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - A quick prescription and annual lecture from a doctor often aren't enough to help people control hypertension. So some clinics now mobilize teams of health pros to motivate and support patients. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/04/526475132/to-bring-down-stubbornly-high-blood-pressure-it-helps-to-have-a-team

item.title: Unfounded Autism Fears Are Fueling Minnesota's Measles Outbreak
item.description: May 3, 2017 - State health officials are struggling to contain a measles outbreak that has sickened mostly Somali-American children. The vaccination rate is low in this tight community that's worried about autism.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 3, 2017 - State health officials are struggling to contain a measles outbreak that has sickened mostly Somali-American children. The vaccination rate is low in this tight community that's worried about autism. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/03/526723028/autism-fears-fueling-minnesotas-measles-outbreak

item.title: Understanding The History Behind Communities' Vaccine Fears
item.description: May 3, 2017 - A measles outbreak in Minnesota's Somali-American community is the latest example of the challenges public health officials face in addressing deeply ingrained concerns about vaccine safety.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 3, 2017 - A measles outbreak in Minnesota's Somali-American community is the latest example of the challenges public health officials face in addressing deeply ingrained concerns about vaccine safety. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/03/526595475/understanding-the-history-behind-communities-vaccine-fears

item.title: Urgent Care Services For Cancer Patients Offer A Gentler ER Alternative
item.description: May 3, 2017 - Some hospitals and oncology practices are setting up urgent care sites tailored to the needs of cancer patients, to help keep them out of the emergency room when complications or side effects arise.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 3, 2017 - Some hospitals and oncology practices are setting up urgent care sites tailored to the needs of cancer patients, to help keep them out of the emergency room when complications or side effects arise. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/03/526594004/urgent-care-services-for-cancer-patients-offer-a-gentler-er-alternative

item.title: Microscopic Cars Square Off In Big Race
item.description: May 2, 2017 - This car race involved years of training, feats of engineering, high-profile sponsorships, competitors from around the world and a racetrack made of gold. And it's invisible to the naked eye.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 2, 2017 - This car race involved years of training, feats of engineering, high-profile sponsorships, competitors from around the world and a racetrack made of gold. And it's invisible to the naked eye. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/02/526605120/microscopic-cars-square-off-in-big-race

item.title: Why Social Media Isn't Always Very Social
item.description: May 2, 2017 - Studies show that people who spend more time on social media sites feel more socially isolated than those who don't. This might be because of a disconnect between our online lives and our real ones.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 2, 2017 - Studies show that people who spend more time on social media sites feel more socially isolated than those who don't. This might be because of a disconnect between our online lives and our real ones. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/02/526514168/why-social-media-isnt-always-very-social

item.title: A New Generation Overthrows Gender
item.description: May 2, 2017 - Parents, schools and elected officials are working to catch up and adapt to the needs of children and teens who don't fit into familiar gender categories.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 2, 2017 - Parents, schools and elected officials are working to catch up and adapt to the needs of children and teens who don't fit into familiar gender categories. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/02/526067768/a-new-generation-overthrows-gender

item.title: Environmentalists, Coal Companies Rally Around Technology To Clean Up Coal
item.description: May 1, 2017 - The industry has been in decline for years, partly because burning coal creates CO2 and warms the atmosphere. But there's a way to capture it — which has drawn praise from traditional enemies.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 1, 2017 - The industry has been in decline for years, partly because burning coal creates CO2 and warms the atmosphere. But there's a way to capture it — which has drawn praise from traditional enemies. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/01/524764617/environmentalists-coal-companies-rally-around-technology-to-clean-up-coal

item.title: A Lazarus Patient And The Limits Of A Lifesaving Stroke Procedure
item.description: May 1, 2017 - About 800,000 people have strokes each year in the U.S. Most are caused by clots that block blood to the brain. In some cases, doctors can remove the clot using a device that looks like a fishing net.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 1, 2017 - About 800,000 people have strokes each year in the U.S. Most are caused by clots that block blood to the brain. In some cases, doctors can remove the clot using a device that looks like a fishing net. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/01/525896731/a-lazarus-patient-and-the-limits-of-a-lifesaving-stroke-procedure

item.title: Yo-Yo Dieting May Pose Serious Risks For Heart Patients
item.description: May 1, 2017 - People with heart disease should keep their weight down, but it can be hard to lose weight and keep it off. Now a study shows big fluctuations may increase the risk of heart attack and stroke.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 1, 2017 - People with heart disease should keep their weight down, but it can be hard to lose weight and keep it off. Now a study shows big fluctuations may increase the risk of heart attack and stroke. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/01/526048767/-yo-yo-dieting-poses-serious-risks-for-heart-patients
